data.title: US Olympic Women's Archery Team Aims for Gold
data.meta_description: The US Olympic women's archery team has secured the maximum 3 quota places for Paris 2024 with opportunities for gold in three events.
data.text:
Introduction to US Olympic Women’s Archery

The US Women’s Archery Team now stands as a top global competitor. Athletes like Casey Kaufhold show great skill. They started their journey at the Archery Olympic trials, where their determination and skill shone.

The US archery team lineup mixes seasoned athletes with new talent. Their goal is to win their first Olympic gold since 1996 in Paris 2024.

Since the 1900 Summer Olympics, archery has been part of Olympic history. Women started competing in 1904. The 1972 Summer Olympics saw the start of the modern era for archery. Now, the sport includes events for both individuals and teams.

The US has secured the maximum 3 quota places for women’s archery in Paris. However, they have only qualified 1 spot so far for the men’s event.

The US still has opportunities to earn 2 more men’s quota places at the Final World Qualification Tournament in June and through the world rankings.

The US Women’s Archery Team aims to make a memorable moment in Paris. Olympic women’s archery introduction connects new fans with its great history. It also shows how these skilled athletes can write an amazing new chapter at the Olympics.

Read more about Olympic archery:

History of Archery in the Olympic Games

Paris 2024 Archery Venue

The Olympic archery events at Paris 2024 will take place at the historic Esplanade des Invalides in the 7th arrondissement (district) in Paris. The Esplanade is a large open space that extends from the Seine River to the Hôtel des Invalides.

This location is close to iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower with ease of access for an unforgettable experience for both athletes and spectators.

Explore the many attractions in Paris and beyond:

Paris Olympics 2024: Spirit of the Games & Local Attractions

Olympics 2024: Explore Paris Attractions

Paris Hidden Gems: Charming Streets, Parks and More

Paris Photography Hotpots and Spectacular Views

Paris Day Trips: Explore Beyond the Olympic City

Olympic Archery Overview

Aspect Detail Event Olympic Archery Competition 2024 Venue Esplanade des Invalides, Paris Capacity 8,000 spectators Dates 25th July to 4th August 2024 Format 5 Recurve Events: Individual (Men & Women), Team (Men & Women), and Mixed Team event Participants 64 men and 64 women Olympic Targets Targets are 122cm in diameter and 70m distance from the archers Scoring Best-of-five sets, three arrows per set

Meet the US Olympic Women’s Archery Team Members

The Women’s Olympic archers for Team USA going to the 2024 Paris Games are full of talent and experience.

Casey Kaufhold stood out with an amazing score of 657 during the individual eliminations. She would go on to win the women’s title in the U.S. Olympic Archery Trials.

Catalina GNoriega joins Casey after impressive performances at the trials despite storms.

Alongside them, Jennifer Mucino-Fernandez caught the eye with her strong performances.

The US Olympic Women’s Archery Team is now getting ready for Paris 2024 led by Casey Kaufhold, currently ranked #1 in women’s recurve in the world.

Since the 1996 Atlanta Games, the USA has not won a gold medal in archery.

In the men’s event, three-time Olympic medalist Brady Ellison won securing a place on the team. Brady brings his experience to the team. His knowledge and motivation are key for the team’s success in Paris.

Casey Kaufhold

Age: 20

Hometown: Lancaster, Pennsylvania

Current World Ranking: #1 in Women’s Recurve Archery

Making her 2nd Olympic appearance

Instagram: @crazy.casey.04

Casey grew up in a family passionate about archery, which sparked her interest from a very young age.

At just 17 years old, Casey represented the USA at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, showing incredible skill and composure. She was the youngest member of Team USA at the Tokyo Games gaining her recognition on the international stage.

Casey trains rigorously and believes in hard work and staying focused on her goals. She serves as an inspiration to young athletes everywhere, demonstrating that age is just a number when it comes to achieving big dreams.

Catalina GNoriega

Age: 21

Hometown: San Diego, California

Current World Ranking: #44 in Women’s Recurve Archery

Making her Olympic debut in Paris

Instagram: @catalina.gn

Catalina Gnoriega is a talented archer representing the United States. She has made significant strides in her archery career at a young age. Catalina competed in the 2018 Youth Olympic Games and has been a key figure in the US archery team.

She has qualified for the Paris 2024 Olympics, marking her debut in the Olympic Games.

Jennifer Mucino-Fernandez

Age: 21

Hometown: Boston, Massachusetts

Current World Ranking: #30 in Women’s Recurve Archery

Making her 2nd Olympic appearance

Instagram: @jennifer.mucino.9

Jennifer Mucino-Fernandez is a talented American archer. She discovered her passion for archery at the age of nine after being inspired by the London 2012 Olympics. Jennifer has been coached by her mother, Rosa Mucino, who learned the sport to support her daughter’s dreams.

Jennifer represented Team USA at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, where she competed in the women’s individual event. She is now preparing to represent the United States in the Paris 2024 Olympics, continuing her journey as a prominent figure in the world of archery.

Learn more about world rankings:

Paris 2024 Top Olympic Archery Contenders

Brady Ellison and Mixed Team Event

The buzz around the Olympic Games Paris 2024 is growing.

People are excited to see how Brady Ellison and Casey Kaufhold will do in the mixed team event. They are a strong team. This will be Brady’s fifth Olympics, and Casey’s second Olympics.

Last year, Ellison showed his skills by becoming the world’s No. 2 in men’s recurve. He earned a spot for the men by winning in a mixed team event. This win highlights how powerful mixed-gender archery teams can be.

Kaufhold, the top U.S. woman in recurve archery, is also ranked world No. 1. This gives the U.S. women’s team a great chance in Paris.

Ellison and Kaufhold’s teamwork proves Team USA is ahead in mixed-gender archery. This format offers more chances to win medals. It also combines the wisdom of age with the energy of youth.

USA Archery tracks the archers’ performance over six stages. Ellison and Kaufhold work well together and push each other to be their best.

Their skills and team spirit are an advantage for Team USA. As they prepare for Paris, their story shows how mixed-gender archery is making its mark.

US Olympic Women’s Archery Team Going for Gold

The US Olympic Women’s Archery Team is preparing for the 2024 Olympics in Paris. They aim to win the gold medals, following a strong legacy.

In archery, the US has won 33 Olympic medals, including 14 gold.

The team faces tough competition, notably from South Korea, which has earned more medals. Despite this, Team USA is committed to doing well in Paris.

At the Tokyo Olympics, South Korea won four gold medals in archery, showing their strength in the sport. However, Paris will have five archery competitions, giving the US more opportunities.

The Paris games will have events for both genders and mixed-gender teams. Teams in these mixed events will be ranked by their combined scores.

Young talent like Casey Kaufhold, the top women’s archer worldwide at 20, will be essential.

As the Paris Olympics near, the US Olympic Women’s Archery Team is focused. They aim to win gold and make their country proud.

Past Olympic Performances and History

The United States has a rich Olympic archery history. From the first games until now, American archers have shown their skill.

In 1996, at the Atlanta Olympics, Justin Huish won gold in both the men’s individual and team events.

American archers like Jay Barrs and Darrell Pace are celebrated. Jay Barrs won gold in Seoul 1988. Meanwhile, Darrell Pace won in Los Angeles 1984 and his teammate, Rick McKinney, came in second.

In 1976, in Montreal, Team USA was outstanding, winning the gold in every event. Then, in 1972, Doreen Wilber won the women’s gold in Munich.

In the past, American archers have shown their excellence time and again. The Tokyo 2020 Olympics, unfortunately, did not bring any medals. Despite this, the history of US archery is filled with inspiring achievements and high standards for current and future athletes.

The early achievements in archery were crucial for future success. In 1972, the USA swept the archery gold medals. And in 1920, Hubert van Innis from Belgium won an incredible nine medals, inspiring archers worldwide.

American women have played a vital role in archery. Luann Ryon won gold in 1976. Denise Parker competed in three Olympics, starting at just 14 in Seoul 1988. And more recently, Lia Coryell won gold at the World Archery Para Championships in 2022.

These achievements are a big part of the Olympic archery legacy.

Current US female archers are working hard to continue this legacy. The rich history of US archery motivates them to aim for the top.

Conclusion

Kaufhold’s rise to be the best in the world shows how serious the US women are. With a focused goal, they are preparing for the team events.

The journey to the Olympics challenges the top archers in the US. They have shown their skill through the Olympic trial qualifications.

The legacy of US archery, started by legends like Darrell Pace, continues to inspire. With the Paris Games approaching, the team’s hard work is aimed at winning gold and adding to the long history of American excellence in archery.

The women of Team USA archery are determined. They aim to make their country proud by winning. Keep an eye on their journey to Olympic glory.
